title: RL34022
content: Congress enacted the FY2008 Consolidated Appropriations Act on December 19, 2007, to fund most of the federal government, including HUD. The funding level provided is lower than initially approved but higher than the President's request. It reduces funding for programs like HOPE VI, HOME, and Community Development Block Grant. The bill also includes a rescission of over $720 million for the Section 8 voucher program. The FY2008 Consolidated Appropriations Act, signed into law on December 19, 2007, funded most federal programs, including HUD, at reduced levels. It included a rescission of over $720 million for the Section 8 voucher program. Various continuing resolutions (CRs) were passed to fund programs at FY2007 levels until the final appropriations bill was signed. Additional emergency CDBG funds were allocated for Louisiana's Hurricane Katrina recovery program. The FY2008 Transportation-HUD funding bill proposed $38.66 billion for HUD, but it was never considered by the Senate due to the President's veto threat over the funding level exceeding his request. HUD's funding primarily comes from discretionary appropriations in annual acts by Congress to address housing issues for low-income households. HUD provides rental assistance programs for the poor, elderly, and disabled, with Public Housing, Section 8 Vouchers, and Section 8 project-based rental assistance being the main funding sources. Block grant programs like HOME and Community Development Block Grants help finance housing and community development activities for low-income families. HUD also focuses on increasing homeownership rates for lower-income and minority households through downpayment assistance and housing counseling programs. The Federal Housing Administration insures mortgages for lower-income home buyers with below-average credit records. The Federal Housing Administration (FHA) provides mortgage insurance for lower-income home buyers and developers of affordable rental buildings. Surplus funds from FHA are used to offset HUD budget costs. In FY2007, Congress approved continuing resolutions to maintain government funding at FY2006 levels. In FY2007, Congress approved a continuing resolution (P.L. 110-5) that funded most programs at their FY2006 levels. The CR specified higher or lower funding levels for some HUD programs, including Tenant Based Rental Assistance, Project-Based Rental Assistance, Public Housing Operating Fund, Indian Housing Loan Guarantee, Homeless Assistance Grants, and Salaries and Expenses. Some HUD accounts were funded above their FY2006 levels, while others were funded below. In FY2007, the 110th Congress approved a supplemental funding bill that made changes to the FY2007 CR, providing additional funding for HUD's Inspector General to oversee Hurricane Katrina funding and clarifying distribution of Section 8 voucher funding.
